Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: My phone buzzes with a message from Mark: “Rough day. Can we talk?” I know he’s been feeling down lately, and as his friend, I want to be there, to listen and offer comfort. I start typing a reply, but then I glance at the clock—ten minutes until Mrs. Evans arrives at the church office. She’s been waiting weeks for this appointment, desperate for spiritual guidance about her ongoing family troubles. As a priest, I can’t let her down; she’s counting on me for counsel and support. But Mark’s words tug at me, reminding me of the promise I made to always be there for him. My mind races, torn between the warmth of friendship and the solemn duty of my calling. I feel the weight of both expectations pressing in, each demanding my presence, each deserving my full attention. My fingers hover over my phone, heart pounding, as I wrestle with which part of myself to honor first.
